bibl.title: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to John A. Ferrell, October 19, 1921

div1.p: Fricks thanks Ferrell for the invitation to attend meeting in malaria control. He requests that the International Health Board fund expenses for H.R. Carter as he feels H.R. Carter's presence is essential.

div1.head: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to John A. Ferrell, October 19, 1921

HEADQUARTERS:
Field Investigations of Malaria
U.S. Public Health Service,
Memphis, Tenn.
October 19, 1921.
Dr. Jno. A. Ferrell,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N.Y.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
On my return from Washington this morning, I find
your authorization for the attendance of the Internation-
al Health Board sanitary engineers engaged in malaria
control at the Hot Springs meeting, for which I thank
you.

In this connection, I took up with the Bureau the mat-
ter of Dr. H. R. Carter attendance at our malaria meetings
and to my great disappointment was advised that there was
no feasible way through which the Bureau could pay Dr.
Carter's travel expenses while in attendance at this meet-
ing. In my judgment, Dr. Carter's presence and advice to
malaria field workers would be of the greatest value to us
and to every phase of the malaria work which as you know
is now passing through a transition period.

I am sure that Dr. Carter would be glad to meet with
us, and that he cannot afford to pay from his own pocket
the expenses incident to such a long trip. For these
reasons, I would strongly recommend that the International
Health Board offer to pay Dr. Carter's expenses to this
meeting solely on the ground that his attendance will be
worth the amount expended because of his long experience
and broad information hearing upon malaria control in the
South.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon.
Medical Officer in Charge Wrote to Ferrell. Oct 22/21
declining to accept, the proposi
tion indicated also to Fricks.
